comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: I am fairly sure that is the SS Orient (yet again - that's no.10). More info - compare with the side view painting - www.laird-bogstown.com/orient 1.php PhMC SS Orient photos - www.flickr.com/search/?ss=2&w=24785917@N03&q=ss+o...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Second thoughts (some of those liners were very similar) - I now think this is the Orient Line's SS 'ORIZABA' on Friday 27 January 1888. moored in Farm Cove for the Centennial Regatta, and photographed from Mrs Macquarie's Chair. Hence all the flags, boats, colour and movement. Described in the Sydney Morning Herald the following day - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13680429 . The Orizaba was wrecked off Western Australia in 1905, and is now a famous dive site - www.museum.wa.gov.au/collections/maritime/march/shipwreck... . See www.flickr.com/photos/49243167@N03/4537807228/ and www.flickr.com/photos/49243167@N03/4535158238/ Comparison photos - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=447782 www.tallis.on.net/images/p13.jpg And the "Orizaba Gavotte" sheet music (!!) - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.mus-an6304260-s1-e

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Prompted by this Henry King photo - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2362663293/

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: I agree beachcomberaustralia - it is 'the Orizaba trimmed up and decorated for the occassion'. Not only have you identified the vessel, but named the very day. Well done.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: beachcomberaustralia: Lookin' like S.S. Orizaba to me. Matches the other known photograph of Orizaba. Position, dressing of the ship and huge number of people aboard match the newspaper description of S.S. Orizaba for the Centennial Regatta. Yachts under canvas are also mentioned in the newspaper description of the day. A wood engraving of the Sydney Centennial Exhibition held by the State Library of Victoria shows a tableau of scenes. At the bottom is "The Regatta" A ship substantially the same as this one and dressed identically to the one in the photograph above is shown, although there are some very minor differences between the foredeck of the wood engraved ship and the one photographed here. This lends further weight to this photograph being of the Centennial Regatta. Here is the wood engraving: www.slv.vic.gov.au/miscpics/gid/slv-pic-aab13938/1/mp006972 I suppose there are books and pamphlets about Sydney's Centennial Celebrations which will confirm that this is a photograph of S.S. Orizaba at that event.

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: This remarkably similar photograph is from the Star Photo Co. collection at the State Library of NSW. It appears to be the same ship - but is it of the same event? The Star Photo Co. operated from 1898-1928. It wasn't operating in 1888. Hmm... Were there subsequent regattas that justified such a grand flagship? Or is it not a Star Photo Co. photograph but one incorrectly attributed because it was among their collection? Sorry beachcomberaustralia, but I'm afraid I've raised more questions than answers!

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: There is something else which may assist. The State Library of New South Wales has a book of pictorial views of Australasia published in the centennial year 1888 by "Phillip-Stephan Photo-Litho. And Typographic Process Company". It has 48 colour plates of which plate No. 10 is "Centennial regatta, Sydney, S.S. Orizaba Flagship" A look at this plate may help in confirmation. The book of views on on restricted access at the SLNSW. I'll see if I can get in there during late June 2010 to have a look at it. The link to the catalogue record is this: library.sl.nsw.gov.au/record=b1996489~S2 Of course, this may prove inconclusive.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Thanks guys for your comments and opinions. I am even more confused by the Orient liners now ( www.simplonpc.co.uk/Orient1.html )! I am not 100% sure that it is the 'Orizaba' on 27/01/1888 myself, but wanted to open discussion about this and other Orient and yachting photos. The "Orizaba Gavotte" (see link above) is a fine piece of fluff - I have been bashing it out on my piano. Originally written for pipe organ by August Wiegand, the first City of Sydney Organist at the new 1890 Centennial Hall Hill organ - www.flickr.com/photos/powerhouse_museum/2362678043/
